title: Will a lethal confrontation involving national military forces of Saudi Arabia and Iran result in at least one fatality for either side in December 2017?
preds: If there is a lethal event, it would be through proxies.
Regional stability for Mid east is very important for energy security. I feel Iran/Hezbollah and Saudi conflict has some world wide implications.

Proxy wars don't count.  Proxy wars are most popular means of signaling threats and determining possible escalation.  As yet, proxy war games are ongoing.  Moreover, direct military aggression requires taking geopolitical and economic risks that neither side is prepared to take.  Thus, only proxy wars will continue in the short-term.

The recent protests in Iran further weaken the current Iranian regime, especially in their ability to stoke regional conflicts.  For Rouhani to maintain his position with the people he must distance himself from the regional conflicts and focus on the economic concerns of the electorate.  This will likely increase the tensions between him and the hardliners in the clerical council.  But either way, Iran will be looking toward domestic politics for the near future.
Such an engagement may occur but it's extremely unlikely it would be of sufficient scale to catch media attention, or even be publicly known.
Likely to occur in Syrian related Confrontation.
There are heightened tensions in the region but not likely to escalate to the level of casualties this year.
Waiting for next year when Saudi military supplies get maxed. Military aggression not likely due to hesitancy by both Iran and Saudi Arabia. If it happens -by accident.
Nobody wants open conflict. Iran and SA are under too much popitical pressure. Proxy war will continue elsewhere.
We  are  almost  done  with December 2017.  No deaths  have  been  reported.
No suggesting of large scale escalation. No time.

So far, the Saudis are using preliminary language, so an immediate escalation of direct conflict is unlikely. Additionally, the Saudis have enough going on within the kingdom without heaping a full-scale war onto their plate. Proxy fighting will continue, though, in Yemen.  Both nations have a unified goal in opposing Jerusalem as the Israeli capital, so they will not disrupt the overall balance of Arab middle eastern power...yet.

While a direct war between Iran and Saudi Arabia is certainly possible, I don't see that it's imminent enough to happen in the next few days. Saudi Arabia doesn't like direct attacks against what it believes to be strong enemies. It prefers to use money, influence and proxies. Iran is trying to push limits and gain control gradually through proxies and isn't wanting a direct attack on Saudi Arabia while it can still gain indirectly.
Little time for this to happen.
Unlikely to escalate to military action.  Extremely unlikely given timeframe
Possibly, but unlikely...again, because we are only six days away until the end of Dec. now.
When people get hot headed and on-the-spot things happen

Despite increasing political tensions and ever increasing proxy engagements throughout the Middle East the odds of direct confrontation seem very low. Any direct engagement would likely be an accident related their respective efforts to covertly interfere with the other nation's military efforts, additionally, any covert military action would likely have grounds for deniability built into the mission, and as such even in the unlikely event that there are fatalities on either side caused by the national military of the other country, the blame would likely be shifted to one of the proxy groups the other nation is already engaged with, further decreasing the odds that a credible news source would gather enough evidence to bring such a story to light by the deadline.
Because it doesn't include proxy war the probability is low.

Not much time left in the year for something like this to happen. Tensions may be high, but only an air strike could occur, likely one to punish Iran for selling the missiles to the rebels. Well south of 10% and definately above 0%. 1-4%. With skew to 1-2.
The missile fire from Yemen into Saudi Arabia was found to be make from Iranian parts. Neither party wants an outright war, but tension are very high
The tension between both sides is public enough that virtually every actor, civilian and military, has a strong incentive to NOT wander into the gunsights of the other.
Yemen "appears" to be a proxy for it iran, but could be a good patsy. I belie e even with occasional rockets, iran is not getting directly involved, at the moment.
Tensions have been rising but I don't think they will escalate to this point in this short time frame.
Yemen is the more likely adversary at this time
Not yet, they are still testing the limits of US foreign policy under Trump.
Proxy wars seem likely to cause deaths on both sides. But by the end of the year it is unlikely to boil over into open confrontation.
Tensions are high and will probably get higher

For at least the second time in as many months, Saudi Arabia announced that it had intercepted a missile fired by Yemen's Houthi rebels at Riyadh. No one was injured. Even so, Saudi Arabia suggested the attack was tantamount to an act of war by Iran. Saudi Arabia claims that Iran is supplying the Houthi fighters with weapons. The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, backed the claim in a fiery news conference last week.

1.) Each side seems to prefer the current proxy war approach. 2.) A rapid change in the power balance would gratify some stakeholders in each country. But much more powerful factions in each country rely on revenue flows that would be imperiled by sudden changes.

The Saudi's need our military backing to engage the Iranians in physical conflict.  The Iranians do not want to call attention to their covert military build-up using the cash received from the Obama Administration to gain a nuclear "deal"so they will avoid physical confrontation on their side.
When US presented missile parts to UN Iran denied they were theirs. They probably are supplying Houthis with arms but unless they have advisors in harms way firing them this is unlikely.

With increased pressure from the Trump administration especially using the nuckear deal as proxy, Iran Is unlikely to want to rock the boat and risk alienating itself from the other partbers of the deal.

Saudi Arabia is said to have a weak military despite US weapon sales so they are unlikely to attack. US would probably side with KSA so Iran will not directly attack. Possible some random Iranian advisor to the Houthis in Yemen might get killed by a Saudi bomb.
Lots of people are going to die in proxy conflicts over the month but I don't think these two are going to fight directly.

Very unlikely. POTUS recognition of Jerusalem as capitol of Israel will focus Iranian soft power on the Levant for the time being. KSA unlikely to directly attack Iranian forces over SCUD missiles in Yemen.

Iran and KSA are locked in more of cold-war type stand off. They don't want to risk losing games and while KSA is concerned and hostile to Iranian influence, they are still internally reorganizing and focused on immediate goals of shifting economies from energy dependence. In the immediate short term, it is highly unlikely.
Generally, war seems highly unlikely nowadays + only 4 weeks left.
The many issues to solve now within Saudi Crown Family makes a new foreing  military involvement improbable
Iran uses Proxies like Hezzbullah and Huthis to fight the Saudis. Still a stray Advisor might kill or be killed.
